content:
‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept because it has a unique goal to figure out how closely linked actors are through shared movies. The straightforward rules for input and output, along with reasonable constraints, make it approachable. The mix of test cases featuring different actors and scenarios adds a nice variety to test basic problem-solving skills.
unique idea and good test cases. Could improve difficulty but not bad.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I mean... there are plenty of resources out there explaining what is BFS and how to do, and I'm not even talking about the amount of Easy BFS puzzles. If someone jumps straight to clash of code with little to no knowledge of such practice and elementary algorithms, then those person expose themselves to have a rough time. To be honest, i'm pretty sick of 20-seconds clashs consisting in printing A*B or similar problems. This one feels just fine to me, perfect balance between difficulty and time required to code.

I've now submitted this as an Easy puzzle. Thanks for your feedback. Please feel free to reject this page now so that it can be discarded as a clash proposal but still kept public for the comments. :)

https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/82284b43f2707615565e26602495bc836f26d
I upvoted the puzzle because it's good, but I can't approve because I don't think most players can do this in 15 minutes.

‚ùå Rejected the contribution.
Comment: I refuse this contribution because I don't think it can be done in less than 5 minutes. It deserves a lot of thought, and even if you have the solution, you need time to implement it. It can make a good puzzle game but too hard for clash of code

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good testcases, original, a bit more difficult than average clash but also doable in less than 5 minutes, for those who don't know BFS it will maybe be difficult, but they will learn important search algorithm, so i guess that's good !
Love the puzzle, not sure it should be a Clash. This is a Medium-level solo puzzle, to my mind. It took me 15 mins just to figure out how to structure the data :)
This is quite hard to understand in reverse because we dont know that were linking to Kevin Bacon. I suggest make actors name in inputs dynamic

Goal
* Suggest to simplify the middle part as:

Given an [[actor_name]] and a number of movies with their casts, determine the bacon number of [[actor_name]], i.e. the minimum number of movies needed to link [[actor_name]] to {{Kevin Bacon}}.

Input
* Suggest not to format "Bacon number" as a constant. Alternatively, suggest to format it in <<bold>> instead.

* Please change the last description as follows:
<<Next [[n]] lines :>> a string [[movie_cast]] in the format [[Movie_name]]{{:}} [[Actor 1]]{{,}} [[Actor 2]]{{,}} ‚Ä¶

Output
* Suggest not to format "Bacon number" as a constant. Alternatively, suggest to format it in <<bold>> instead.

Constraints
* Please format "," and ":" as {{constants}} and remove the quotation marks.

Thanks.

If you want to test out some other actors' Bacon numbers, you can try here:
https://oracleofbacon.org/

Game Wikipedia page here:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Six_Degrees_of_Kevin_Bacon

Thanks. :)

Implemented them all.

I get your point. I think having it link to Kevin Bacon is core to the idea though, so I don't want to make it any actor to any actor for this clash idea. I'm happy to remove Reverse if it does seem too hard for most people.

I have got hints in the Test case names "# Degrees of Kevin Bacon" and also in the Stub Generator which has "# 6 Degrees of Kevin Bacon!" at the top and a write statement to print "Bacon_number" at the end. Still, might be too much to ask for people to decipher the puzzle in Reverse. I'd rather keep it as it is and remove Reverse mode if it's too complex though. Rather than change the concept to keep Reverse mode.

Thanks for the feedback. The data stuff can be tricky, it's certainly going to be a tough clash for some players. But if you are well-versed in Breadth-First Search I think it's solvable quite quickly.

I've disabled Reverse and Shortest mode so that clashers will only need to focus on solving the idea. If it gets rejected, then I'll submit as a puzzle.

I've now submitted this as an Easy puzzle. Thanks for your feedback.

https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/82284b43f2707615565e26602495bc836f26d

I've now submitted this as an Easy puzzle. Thanks for your feedback.

I've now submitted this as an Easy puzzle. Thanks for your feedback.

I've now submitted this as an Easy puzzle. Thanks for your feedback.

https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/82284b43f2707615565e26602495bc836f26d

I could update it to medium, but I've made the test cases intentionally very simple and lacking in multiples paths to Kevin Bacon (which would make BFS more necessary), so I don't think it warrants medium difficulty unless/until I add harder test cases.
or u can change the answer to n degrees to bacon
OK sure, nice idea. The stub generated answer is now "N degrees to Kevin Bacon" instead of "Bacon_number"

Thank you.

Just a note and not really asking for more changes: the reason why I omitted [[n]] when I suggested the revised middle paragraph was that, well, it would be simpler. It isn't really necessary to give that many details when explaining the goal; the details can be left to Input section. This is just to let you understand my reasoning üòâ.
